# Reference: How to connect via SSH to BDCS-CE

Welcome to Oracle Big Data Cloud Service - Compute Edition (BDCS-CE).

This tutorial was built for BDCS-CE version 17.3.1-20 as part of the New Data Lake User Journey: <https://github.com/oracle/learning-library/tree/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake>.  Questions and feedback about the tutorial: <david.bayard@oracle.com>

**Contents**

+ About Setting up your BDCSCE Environment
+ Enabling SSH Network Access
+ Connecting via SSH
+ Setting up the zeppelin user with sudo access
+ Configuring yum and pip
+ Installing the python swiftfs client
+ Next Steps

As a reminder, the documentation for BDCS-CE can be found here: <http://docs.oracle.com/cloud/latest/big-data-compute-cloud/index.html>


**NOTE: You need to run all of the steps *one at a time, in order* in this notebook from top to bottom.  Some steps are performed outside the notebook, so be sure to carefully read through the notebook and follow all instructions.**

# About Setting up your BDCSCE Environment

This tutorial will walk you through a series of steps to help customize your BDCS-CE environment.  In particular, you will login to the Zeppelin server via SSH and add the zeppelin user to the linux "sudo" user list.  This will allow us to use the "sudo" utility within our notebook via the Shell interpreter, which will let us configure some extensibility utilities like yum and python's pip.

# Enabling SSH Network Access

Our first step is to enable network access to our BDCS-CE server via the SSH protocol.  You will do this from the BDCS-CE Service Console.  Here are the steps:

 + From the BDCS-CE Service Console, navigate to Access Rules for your BDCS-CE instance.  

 + Then, on the Access Rules page, enable the ssh (port 22) access rule by choosing Enable from the clickable menu under the Actions column as shown below.
![Enable SSH](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/AllowSSH.gif "Enabling SSH")

# Connecting to your BDCS-CE Master Server via SSH

For the next step, you will need to connect your BDCS-CE server via SSH as the linux user opc.  

You can review how to connect to your BDCS-CE server via SSH by:

+ Navigate to the product documentation at <http://docs.oracle.com/cloud/latest/big-data-compute-cloud/bigdata-compute-cloud-tasks.html> .  
+ Click “Tasks” in the navigation bar on the left hands side of the screen.  
+ Then click the “Connect to a node through SSH” topic under the “Access the Service” category.
![ssh](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/SSH.gif "SSH Instructions")




### Hint for Windows Users: 
Windows users typically use Putty for SSH.  If you generated a private key via the web console during BDCS-CE instance creation, the downloaded private key will be in openSSH format.  Therefore, you will need to run the puttygen command on your private key to convert it to ppk format.  Here is an example:

![ssh1](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/PuttyPrivateKey.gif "Windows-create ppk")

Next, Windows users will specify the location of the private key (in .ppk format) when connecting.  Here is an example:
![ssh2](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/PuttySSH.gif "Windows-putty connect")


## Use the above instructions and connect now via SSH to your BDCS-CE Master Server
![ssh](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/snap0011403.jpg "Connect as opc via ssh")

paragraphs.text:
%md
# Setting up the zeppelin user with sudo access

 + Now that you are connected as opc to your BDCS-CE Master Server, type the following command (minus the quotes): "sudo visudo"
![visudo](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/snap0011404.jpg "Setting up sudo for zeppelin user")

 + Then type shift-G to move to the bottom of the file.

 + Then type the lowercase letter o to open the edit mode
![visudo](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/snap0011405.jpg "Setting up sudo for zeppelin user")

 + Then type the following line:
zeppelin   ALL=(ALL)  NOPASSWD: ALL
![visudo](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/snap0011406.jpg "Setting up sudo for zeppelin user")

 + Then hit the ESCAPE key, then type the colon : key, then type the lowercase w followed by the lowercase q
![visudo](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/snap0011407.jpg "Setting up sudo for zeppelin user")

 
 + Then hit ENTER


Here is an animation of the above:
![visudo](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/oracle/learning-library/master/workshops/journey2-new-data-lake/images/300/visudo.gif "Setting up sudo for zeppelin user")

#### To check if this worked, run the paragraph immediately below.  The output should say "root".  If not, then sudo is not setup right for this tutorial.

msg.data:
Setting up the zeppelin user with sudo access

  • Now that you are connected as opc to your BDCS-CE Master Server, type the following command (minus the quotes): “sudo visudo”

  • Then type shift-G to move to the bottom of the file.

  • Then type the lowercase letter o to open the edit mode

  • Then type the following line:
    zeppelin ALL=(ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL

  • Then hit the ESCAPE key, then type the colon : key, then type the lowercase w followed by the lowercase q

  • Then hit ENTER

Here is an animation of the above:

To check if this worked, run the paragraph immediately below. The output should say “root”. If not, then sudo is not setup right for this tutorial.

# Configuring yum and pip
Next, we will run a script to configure the installation utilities yum and pip.  These are standard utilities that make it easier to add additional open source modules to our BDCS-CE environment.  Be sure you have completed the above steps first, then run the paragraph below.

msg.data:
Configuring yum and pip

Next, we will run a script to configure the installation utilities yum and pip. These are standard utilities that make it easier to add additional open source modules to our BDCS-CE environment. Be sure you have completed the above steps first, then run the paragraph below.

paragraphs.title: Commands to setup yum and pip
paragraphs.text:
%sh
# be sure to have increased the SH interpreter timeout as shown above or this will likely end in a SIGTERM error before it finishes
echo "currently installed yum repositories (will initially be empty)"
sudo ls -l /etc/yum.repos.d/
echo "download latest ol6 repo file"
sudo bash -c "cd /etc/yum.repos.d; wget -nc http://yum.oracle.com/public-yum-ol6.repo; ls -l"
echo "clean yum metadata"
sudo yum clean metadata 2>&1
echo "running yum to install python-setuptools. may take 5 to 10 minutes to setup yum cache initially."
sudo yum -y install python-setuptools 2>&1
echo "after yum"
echo "running easy_install"
sudo easy_install pip 2>&1
echo "after easy_install"
echo "use pip to upgrade setuptools"
sudo pip install --upgrade setuptools 2>&1
echo "after upgrade setuptools"
echo "done"

%md

Before you continue, be sure to have run the paragraph above to setup yum and pip.  Do keep in mind that it may take 5 to 10 minutes for the above paragraph to run to completion the first time.

# Installing the swift object store command line utility

Next, we will install the "swift" command line tool.  This is a command-line utility that simplifies working with the Oracle Storage Cloud Object Store.  The Oracle Object Store supports the industry standard OpenStack Object Storage API.  This OpenStack Object Storage API is known as "swift".  The "swift" command line is written in Python and we will use the pip utility to install it.

You can find more details about the swift command line tool here: <https://docs.openstack.org/developer/python-swiftclient/cli.html>

paragraphs.title: Commands to install python swiftclient
paragraphs.text:
%sh
echo "use pip to install python-swiftclient"
sudo pip install python-swiftclient==2.7.0 2>&1
echo "after swiftclient"
echo "testing swiftclient"
swift --help
echo "done"
